body: Ping @granders @mjsax @dguy for reviews.
@junrao I updated the patch to address your reviews.
Jenkins failure are un-related and is tracked in a separate JIRA.
LGTM
@dguy I'm wondering if it's possible to add a test or two on concurrency (querying while someone is inserting)? I only ask since you know how to write excellent tests.

Thanks for the PR. As discussed in the JIRA, we should also fix `RecordsIterator` (assuming that it suffers from the same issue as it looked like it did when I checked). Also, we should call `close` in every usage, not just `LogSegment` IMO.
@ijuma if it's ok with you, I'd rather do the change to the client code in another PR, to keep changes relatively small and reviewable. Thoughts?
It's OK to do that part in a separate PR. Can you please file a JIRA for that then?
No problem. I'll finish up the code on this PR and then write that JIRA.
LGTM
LGTM at a high level, I still need to look more at the details next.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.0.

@guozhangwang, the agreed process is that we should add a JUnit test whenever a system test uncovers a bug that was not caught by a JUnit test. Is there a reason why that wasn't done here? If not, can we file a JIRA for that please?
Thanks for fixing the system test failure by the way. :)
@ijuma Yes I'm working on that right now, while I'm making a pass of all the streams unit tests. I merged this fix just to unblock system test Jenkins build.
Awesome, thanks.
LGTM

@ijuma I think I've fixed everything here. Note that some of the callers of this code rely on the iterator being a scala `Iterator`, so the code got a bit more complex, but nothing unreasonable I don't think.
@junrao It's been a while since the PR was updated and passed system tests. Do you see anything further that needs to be addressed? Thanks.
Also, in DumpLogSegments, could we dump the timestamp in the .log file too?

@becketqin : I made another pass and left a few more comments. It would be good if you can run some performance tests to see if there is any degradation. For instance, with this PR, we will need to read the last entry of each time index during broker startup. Not sure how much impact this will have on starting time. So, it will be good to test this out.
@gwenshap You originally asked for this, so review by you would be nice.
@vahidhashemian : Sorry for the delay. Looks good. Just had a minor comment.
@junrao Thanks for taking another look. I updated the patch as you suggested. Do you think another system test is required?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

The new fix that I mentioned in my earlier comment adds [minimal changes](https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/2ff9550...ce01d72#diff-03237b1458dba015b275a7875232d3ec) (go to `Files Changed` tab and find `SubscriptionState.java`) to the original `SubscriptionState.java`.

IMO, the implementation is more readable in what I proposed ([here](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1572/files#diff-03237b1458dba015b275a7875232d3ec)) in the merged pull request, but that solution seems to bring some inconsistency (causing intermittent test failures) that I still have no explanation for.

@ewencp It's likely that the update is getting stale metadata. In my local test I have been able to get all three pattern tests (`testPatternSubscription`, `testSubsequentPatternSubscription`, `testPatternUnsubscription`) to fail after enough tries. There are a total of 5 `subscribe` calls in these methods and I have been able to get all of them fail the assertion in one try or another. What's more interesting is when I revert the changes to `SubscriptionState.java`and use an alternate fix (as explained [here](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1594)) (note this alternative still uses the metadata update call) I am no longer able to reproduce the failures locally (that PR also passed jenkins tests twice). I'll try to enable logging as you suggested and will share if I find anything interesting.

@vahidhashemian Yeah, my concern is that we're not really fixing the underlying issue. The tests may just be fundamentally broken if they are relying on the topic creation to be propagated to all brokers before using the topics, but I don't think anything in the test actually puts that barrier in place. Certainly the large timeouts and low refresh interval seems like it should work, but it seems like something else is going unexpectedly wrong. I'd be wary of merging #1594 given that we don't really understand why it helps improve things.
@rekhajoshm, I only now noticed that your PR is for the `0.10.0` branch. It should target `trunk` instead.
LGTM
LGTM, merged to trunk.

the autoRebalanceScheduler is running for the parttion rebalance and this thread want the controllerLock

Thanks a lot @HenryCaiHaiying !

Thanks.

Reverting the change may be a little extreme until we understand the cause of the failure (I actually preferred the use of the enum). I haven't been able to reproduce the failure locally in order to debug, but I can try on jenkins.

@hachikuji, yeah, that's why no-one merged this yet. However, the failures happen often enough that it's affecting other PRs. If we can't get to the bottom of it soon, we may have to either revert the original PR or merge this one.

The only way I have been able to get either of the three pattern tests to fail has been running them together. I disable all other tests and let these three to be the remaining active tests. Running single tests has not resulted in  a failure for me so far.
@ijuma I found another issue that's related to brokers leaking GZIP memory, and I'd like to work it in here. Going to close until I have that piece in.
@ijuma could you take a look at this?
Thanks for the follow up review @junrao. I updated the patch based on the feedback.

@vahidhashemian I think I see what's going on. It looks like there's a race condition with the initial metadata fetch and the initial rebalance. We don't actually ensure that the metadata is fresh before joining initially, but we request the metadata update. If that metadata update arrives while the rebalance is still pending (for example, when the join group is still inflight), then we will lose track of the fact that we need to rebalance again to reflect the change to the topic subscription. This seems to be a general problem that we haven't considered before. Any metadata update which changes the topic subscriptions and arrives with a rebalance in progress will essentially be ignored.

@hachikuji Thanks a lot for the explanation and the suggested fix. I tested it a bit and could not reproduce the failures anymore. Should I update this PR with this fix? Or you'll create a new PR? Thanks.
@vahidhashemian I think it makes sense to do it here. I'll open another JIRA to make sure we solve the general problem, but I think this is a necessary part of the solution.
@hachikuji Sounds good. Then I'll go ahead and update this PR. Thanks.
Review by @norwood @dguy @mjsax @enothereska .
FYI, here's a link to the JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3949.

@kunickiaj @gwenshap @ijuma this seems to be a wrong fix . When we acquire a TGT it usually has the following data
Valid Starting 07/11/16 15:19:39
Valid Expires 07/12/16 15:19:39
renew until 07/11/16 15:19:39

Client must renew the ticket before the expiry time.  
Here is more info
"The expiration time for the current instance of a session ticket is held in the endtime field. Just as for nonrenewable session tickets, endtime is the value of the starttime field plus the maximum ticket life specified by the Kerberos policy. A client holding a renewable ticket must present it to the KDC for renewal before the endtime is reached and present a fresh authenticator as well."

https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc961966.aspx
Thanks @hachikuji please have a look. build error unrelated to this PR. thanks.
@ijuma Would you be able to take a look at this when you have some time? Thank you...
LGTM

@harshach, thanks for the comment. I quote an additional part from the documentation:

"When the KDC receives a session ticket for renewal, it checks a second expiration time held in the renew-till field. This time is set when the ticket is first issued; the value is the session ticket's starttime plus the maximum cumulative ticket life specified by the Kerberos policy. When the KDC renews the ticket, it checks to see that the renew-till time has not yet arrived. If it has not arrived, the KDC issues a new instance of the session ticket with a later endtime and a new session key."

So, we are checking the renew-till field ourselves and not renewing it in that case. Are you suggesting that we should not check that field and only let the KDC check it? It seems to me that it would result in the same behaviour, but potentially more calls to the KDC.

By the way, I did come across a few bugs in `KerberosLogin` a while back and created an initial PR:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1522/files
Any chances to have my pull requested accepted?
@junrao I updated the patch based on your review.
Just one question to verify. Otherwise LGTM.
LGTM
@ijuma want to take a look now? I found there's a leak where we uncompress messages during handling of `ProduceRequest` (that we were hitting in production).
@granthenke : Thanks for the patch. LGTM

Sounds good @ijuma. I looked into SASL scenario and it looks like SASL is a bit off than other scenarios where we handle `ApiVersionRequest` in `SaslServerAuthenticator` itself, which means if a client wants to get api versions before SASL authentication, it is allowed. I think in KIP-43 we wanted to add this support to let clients know supported versions of `SaslHandshakeRequest`. Do we currently have a reason to do so? Maybe @rajinisivaram will have some thought here. The current changes will work even for SASL scenario, however if we really want to handle multiple versions of `SaslHandshakeRequest`, we need to get api versions before SASL authentication, and we have following options for that.
1. Move down whole api version checking from `NetworkClient` to `KafkaChannel`. Have `KafkaChannel` maintain supported api versions. Clients will access api versions info from the channel.
2. As Sasl authentication has a special handling for `ApiVersionRequest`, only have api versions fetched for the Sasl scenario in `authenticator` and put a check in `NetworkClient` to go to `READY` state from `CONNECTED`, skipping `CHECKING_API_VERSIONS`.

Thoughts?
Left a few comments, otherwise LGTM.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branch.

@ijuma @junrao @gwenshap @guozhangwang @ewencp
Sorry for closing and reopening! I thought that's the only way to recheck it so it doesn't throw the error fixed by https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/98dfc4b307c2e41a7fb0fff330048aa9ff78addd
@SinghAsDev @harshach Thanks for the reviews. addressed review comments

@SinghAsDev At the moment, there is only one version of `SaslHandshakeRequest`, but it will still be good to consider how this can be validated as well while you are doing the others. Perhaps a separate request from `SaslClientAuthenticator`to fetch only the supported versions of `SaslHandshakeRequest` would be neater? That way, you don't need to propagate the list of used APIs to the authenticator or the versions back to the NetworkClient. The rest of the code can stay as is. It would mean an additional `ApiVersionsRequest` for Sasl, but perhaps that is ok. If that is the agreed approach, you could add a comment in `SaslClientAuthenticator` and perhaps defer implementation until a new version of `SaslHandshakeRequest` is required. What do you think?
LGTM

@omkreddy The changes in `ConsumerCoordinator` are inconsistent with the proposal in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3396 to address the security issue in the current code that returns unauthorized topics to clients. An option would be to ignore unauthorized topics that match patterns and only subscribe to authorized topics that match the pattern without throwing an exception.

@rajinisivaram  Thanks for the details.  My concern is ignoring unauthorized topics will make debugging harder for authorization related issues. Since this is a critical issue, may be we can fix now and we can revisit after KAFKA-3396 and KIP-4.
@theduderog have a look when you can. I think the content is there, however you might want to do a subsequent PR where you format stuff how you like.

@guozhangwang The refactoring to the inner stores looks good. However, I'm having a hard time understanding how the restoration process originally failed and what exactly is currently fixing it. Perhaps additional comments around that code and/or an integration test that exposes the problem would help?

One meta comment: we are currently exposing the following classes as public interfaces to users, under “state” sub-package:

QueryableStoreType
QueryableStoreTypes
ReadOnlyKeyValueStore
ReadOnlyWindowStore
StateStoreProvider

I’m wondering if we can move some of these classes into internals to minimize the number of user-facing interface classes? For example StateStoreProvider’s API currently is only used for state/internals classes.
Good point @guozhangwang - i'll take a look at what can move. Thanks
